The way to go!!. The only way to travel to Sydney to avoid traffic and parking hassles. Regular, on time departures and taking 30 minutes each way, you are dropped at Circular Quay in central Sydney. A fabulous view awaits when rounding the headland after leaving Manley, as the majestic Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House sweep into view. These iconic landmarks really are best appreciated from the water. If you can board early and head to the front of the vessel so that you can get a prime outdoor seat, then you will get the most from the trip. Adult return ticket is $15 (AUS), so probably about the cheapest way to get into central Sydney.

Free to see the harbour if you have mymulti3 card. I don't know how many weekly passes that are offer, but we bought the mymulti 3 for $63 (as we also planned to use it to go to Blue Mountain). With the pass, it's free for any ferry, train, bus etc. We went to the Manly ferry twice - in an evening and an afternoon. The time we went in the evening, it was very windy and quite chilly. We went another time in an afternoon and it was nice and calm. We could see the opera house at different angles. It was just relaxing and definitely worth a try.At Manly, we spent 30 mins walking along the street to see the stores then hop back to the next one.The ferry runs every 30 mins is equipped with washroom. If you have time, you should try the ferry from Circular Quay to Balmain too. The ferry stops at different places (Darling Harbour, Luna Park etc)and you can see the harbour even more.

Get the best view. Went by Manly Ferry on a day trip to Manly. Ours was a Sunday trip and yes, the ferry does get busy, especially after 9am when the main tourist crowd wakes up. We were on a 10am one and much as it was busy everyone had a seat and there were some empties, as far as I could see. The ferry has two decks, both with large "inside" seating areas, "outside" area on the lower deck is standing room only, but the top deck one has benches. There is no organised queue system so when the ferry is ready for boarding there can be a bit of a stampede, but everybody gets on board. If you are after the Sydney Harbour views and photos of the Opera House & the Bridge, you've got to bag a spot on the top deck outside. Be prepared to jostle with other photographers for a good shot - I wasn't and suddenly everybody was up and the small area got very busy. The ferry goes right past the Opera House almost immediately after it leaves the dock. Later there are some spectacular harbour views with the bridge right in front of you.The journey is a quick 30 min and on a quiet sunny day it was an excellent experience - short enough not to get bored (essential for those with young kids :-), but long enough to enjoy the fact that you are sailing, it presented some great photo opportunities and was very inexpensive.We travelled on a Sunday Family day pass - $2.50 per person covers a full day of unlimited travel on Sydney train/bus/ferry, which worked well for our party of five.
On time and cheap. Everything good on time and not so croudy. It fit it's purpose for the tourists. The most important not so expensive. 5-7$ for a trip is nothing.

Relaxing. Lovely relaxing way to travel around Sydney.
Could sit inside or out depending on the weather conditions.
Had a coffee once reached the town.

Good value way to do the Harbour. This is a great value way to visit the Harbour without paying a fortune. Get an Opal card and it is even cheaper, especially if you use the Sunday cap of $2.50. Note that the ferry can get busy so queue early if you want an outside seat. A must do on any Sydney itinerary.

Don't do this on a weekend!. Made the mistake of doing this on a sunny Sunday afternoon. The boat was so jammed with people in both directions that I couldn't get anywhere near a view. (Why do people take the window seats and then sit there playing on their smartphones and not actually looking out the window? Come on.) It would have been lovely on a more relaxed weekday though - if you're after the view, pick a more relaxed time of the week to make the trip (or at least get yourself to the front of the ferry queue so you get a good seat!)
Great. Manly Ferries are great for a short travel. There are some things to do on the Manly Ferries. You can eat, drink.
Great view of city...and not expensive. Great way to see the city from the water. We were visiting friends in Manly while visiting Sydney. Nice way to go to dinner, see the city and get a boat ride.

Who needs Staten Island when you have Manly!. Instead of taking a costly harbour cruise, get yourself onto one, or many of the fine ferries that run from Circular Quay to various points in the greater Sydney area. My all time favourite remains the Manly ferry. If you are staying in the suburbs and happen to have a daily (or weekly!) travelcard, the ferry trip is also included.Get there early so you can get an outside seat, sit back and take in the sights.Spend your day at Manly, hop back on the ferry and see the sights again, in a different light depending on the time of day. Just glorious!

An Inexpensive Cruise on the Harbour. It’s a must to do if you visit Sydney. If you have an opal card it only costs $2.50 to travel all day ON A SUNDAY. Really good value and an excellent way to enjoy a cruise on the harbour. Be early in the queue if you want to sit outside as at peak times the ferry gets pretty full. Great photo opportunities.

Cheapest way to get a great tour of the harbour. Don't waste your money on an expensive harbour tour - just take the F1 (slower boat) to Manly for just $15 AUD return and take in all of the main sights on the way to Manly. The 30 minute journey flies by with so much to see and the added bonus is that you end up in Manly, which is another great place to visit if you have a few days in Sydney.Once on the other side make sure that you allocate a few hours to do the Manly scenic walk and drop by for a spot of brunch at the Brevel Cafe.

Sydney's Manly Ferry. For anyone with limited or lots of time in Sydney, take the manly Ferry - not the fast one.For a miniscule sum you'll get a fabulous tour of this magnificent harbour.A return trip and allowing for a couple of hours in Manly, will take only about a half day. On arrival in Manly, walk the few hundred meters through the mall known as The Corso to the ocean beach and lots of beach front restaurants

Manly Ferry Experience. I caught the Manly Ferry departing from Wharf 3 from Circular Quay ... on the way out the ferry passed by a huge Luxury Liner Ship docked at the International Terminal before heading away from the famous Harbour Bridge and passing the Opera House and Fort Dennison which used to be an old prison which only 1 person "Captain Thunderbolt" managed to escaped from. as the ferry passed before the main heads of Sydney Harbour as it swung towards Manly ... the ferry experienced some side to side movements best to go while the weather is a bit windy or storm ... you get the best experience "hope you don't get sea sick".

Great way to see the harbour. I live in Sydney and use the ferry reularly to get to the city. Its a great way to see harbour and city it takes about 30mins each way. The weekends can be problematic as the beaches are popular with Sydney people. It is best to get an early ferry out of Sydney and return early afternnon to avoid crowds on weekends.A night trip is fantastic on a warm night .

cheapest harbour cruise. Lovely trip across the harbour to Manly, The ferry is a commuter so it is not luxurious, the views are beautiful you can see the harbour bridge, opera house, fort denison, you may even see a whale. When you get to Manly you can walk along the harbour, or along the corso to the ocean. There are plenty good places to get lunch/ dinner or a drink.
GREAT VIEW AND COMFORTABLE. It is a great ferry to go to Manly. YOu are comfortable, can sit outside or inside and the best view of Sydney. THey are always on time

don't miss. Link via Sydney Harbour from Circular Quay to Manly Wharf taking in the sights of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge and the inner coastline of magnificent Sydney Harbour. A short and leisurely 40 minute trip. Once in Manly there is an aquarium and the magnificent Manly Beach with a large number of restaurants and hotels and plenty to keep you occupied. A full day in Manly and surrounds is a must. I'm a little biased as have lived in the area around Manly for 50 years. God's country. This ferry trip is for everyone and should take in The Rocks area and Manly Beach if you are visiting and staying in Sydney.

Great perspective of Sydney Harbour. A ferry trip across the harbour from Circular Quay to Manly gives some excellent views of the harbour, the Harbour Bridge, Opera House and Fort Denison. It is one of the 'musts' to do in Sydney. At Manly, take a walk up the mall to Manly Beach and thus see the Pacific Ocean. The ferry births at the inner harbour side, not the ocean side. There are walks along the ocean front including a somewhat steep walk up to North Head for great views. The best way across the harbour is on the ferry rather than the fast cat. as one can go out on the deck of the ferry.

ferry with a view. The Manly Ferry is a very pleasant way to travel, not only for business people going to and from work but for the retired who want an easy way into the city from Manly.The ferries run on time, are reasonably clean and the staff helpful.Traveling over the weekend gives one a leisurely look at the harbour en route.

Cheapest way to cruise on Sydney Harbour. A marvelous way to experience the sights of the harbour without having to pay for an expensive and mediocre lunch package. Sure, you won't get the commentary - but you'll see the beautiful harbour as the locals do. Stand at the bow or grab one of the outside chairs to feel the wind in your hair. It can get chilly (and sometimes wet) outside though, which is why many of the locals stay inside. There is also loads to do in Manly - walk to Queenscliff to Shelly Beach and even to North Head, visit the surf & fashion shops, eat at the many and varied restaurants and bars. Usually the locals tip is to steer clear of the Corso and find a restaurant in one of the many lane-ways or at the wharf.

Manly Ferry. The Manly ferry is a quick and easy way of getting from Circular Quay to Manly Wharf.The only thing i would say is its a bit pricey if you are on a budget.Go early in the morning to beat the crowds as it gets really busy from lunchtime onwards.

A great Day Out. This is a great way to enjoy a day out in Sydney. Take a ferry ride from Circular Quay to Manly and enjoy spectacular views of the Opera House , the Sydney Harbour Bridge and many other parts of Sydney Harbour. I live in Sydney and I always enjoy this trip - always have, always will.Also, very inexpensive.

One of the world's cheapest and best experiences. It is so simple to walk to Circular Quay in Sydney, purchase a ferry ticket, hop on the ferry and travel across to Manly (or to any other of the many ferry dockings along Sydney Harbour). But of all of them, I love the Manly ferry because it takes a while to reach Manly and it gives me time to look at all the passing suburbs and the endless harbour marine traffic. Whether its a wet and windy day or a blue sky sunny day, the colour of the water, the movement of the ferry, the people around me on the ferry, and the endlessly changing vistas of one of the world's great cities, all excite and inspire me. Such a cheap and rich pleasure. I always make a point of taking a return ferry trip somewhere on the Harbour every time I visit Sydney. I feel fresh and clean and reinvigorated by the end of the journey.

SYDNEY HARBOUR. The cheapest and easiest way to see Sydney Harbour. If you are visiting from overseas on a budget or a larger family, this will give you the sights of the harbour and a fun day in Manly as well

Harbour Cruise on a Budget. Take the Manly ferry from Circular Quay for a beautiful, scenic 30 minute harbour cruise. Enjoy Manly's many attractions like scenic walks, Manly Sea Life Sanctuary, a great variety of restaurants & bars & of course swimming - either in the Harbour or at the beach.

Scenic Cruise. We bought a day trip ticket which allowed us to use the trains and other public transport incuding the ferry so took the ferry to Manly. The weather was not ideal and it started pouring when we got there so just had to wait for the return ferry! Will have to attempt it again in better weather.

Great ferry experience. Totally recommend doing this 30 min journey from Circular quay to Manly. We had drink at manly foreshore and fortunate to have a sunny weather and go around the markets that day.Coming back to Circuilar Quay is my favourite as the sun was setting the ferry was greeted by the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Kirribilli House. You don't have to be super early to score a front seat.Negative, depending on the tourist on the boat will make the experience enjoyable.

Great cheap harbour cruise!. Why not do as the locals do! A trip on the Manly ferry is a must do when in Sydney. You get a great leisurely view of much of what Sydney Harbour has to show, plus a visit to Manly on top! Going past the heads can be exciting aswell if there is a bit of a swell! Once in Manly, walk down the Corso to the surf beach, head right at the beach and you get a beautiful walk along to Shelly Beach and great views up the coastline of the Northern Beaches.

Best harbour tour at sn excerlent price. No need to take one of those expensive harbour boat tours which can cist $150 per person. Just jump on the ferry to manly. For about $15 return trip you get an amsxing eye full of Sydney from the harbour, the Opera house, harbour bridge up closs and city view. Also ypu get 30 minutes each way to sit back and look at all of the harbour side suburbs as you ssil past. Brake your trip half way eith a stop over at manly beach by having fish and chips for lunch.

Time well spent. This is probably the best way to see the eastern part of the harbour. The trip from Circular Quay to Manly takes just shy of 40 minutes and there is always something to see as you pass close by the Opera House, Fort Denison, the naval base at Garden Island and Sydney Heads.Outside seating at the bow is limited and tourists make a mad dash to fill it, so aim to be near the head of the queue on the wharf if that is where you want to sit.

Good way to see Sydney Harbour. Just a few minute walking from the Circular Quay station, we bought the ticket. The ferry is quite good. It's a great way to see the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Luna Park, etc. We chosen the trip around 5:30 to enjoyed the sunset on the ferry and it's so wonderful.

Beautiful harbour. A must do when you visit Sydney. Catch the ferry (not the fast one) over to Manly and stroll to the beach. Ferry is only 30 minutes across the beautiful harbour. If you're lucky you'll also get a little swell as you pass the open ocean.

Good way to see Sydney. These cruises are a great way to see Sydney. Get the open top ones for a real windy blast of the harbour and great views of the opera house and bridge. A must do for any tourist. Manly is a nice beach and little shops area.

Don't miss this!!!!!. What a way to see the most beautiful harbour in the world. The views are spectacular you can see the City, Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Luna Park and some of the most expensive real estate in Sydney. I have lived in Sydney all my life, except for overseas trips, but still can't think of a better place to take visitors. If you time it well, you can get a sunny daytime ride, have fish and chips on the beach and then walk around to South Steyne. Come back for a drink in the pub on the esplanade and then the ferry back to the city as the sun is setting. A cheap day but a priceless experience.

A Workhorse for some; a Delight for others!. The Manly Ferry to and from Circular Quay is first and foremost a means of daily commuting for Sydney workers and families, however the great thing for tourists is that it provides unsurpassed views of Sydney Harbour, northern shores and the iconic Bridge and Opera House. The classic design of Manly Ferry is easily identifiable as it wends its way in and out of the harbour. On board you do get some 'open water' swell outside of the Heads, but generally it is a reasonably calm trip - of course this will be weather dependent. Cost for a return trip to Manly is a reasonable $14.80, and much cheaper if you are eligible for a seniors discount. Returning from Manly early on a Saturday night, it was interesting to see the number of young, 'dolled-up' Manly locals travelling over to Sydney for a 'night on the town'. Our night views of the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House and city skyline were a tourist's delight, but didn't seem to have much attraction for the locals who were not going to be distracted from their conversations. We did The Spit to Manly Scenic Walk and saw several of the ferries from the clifftops as they moved in a out of the Heads.

The ferry ride is a beautiful and simple way to see the harbour.. It's actually quite a magnificent view from the ferry. The Harbour Bridge looms over you as you leave the terminal and cruise past the Opera House. Then you cruise down the centre of the harbour past small islands and an island fort. You pass the entrance to the harbour which can be a wild ride in a strong well or inclement weather (also fun!). The views are extraordinary, if you are clever, take some binoculars. It gets very busy on the weekend and at peak hour so time your ride for the best effect. Sunset is beautiful, night is romantic and a daytime ride gives you a fantastic look at the most beautiful harbour in the world (yes, I'm biased). The trip is about 30min each way, and you have the suburb and beaches to explore at Manly.

Classic ferry ride. Far more genuine, not to mention cheaper, than the tour boats. Go at sunset from Circular Quay, then return immediately to see the harbor, the Bridge and Opera House lighted at night. Could be crowded--but it's romantic.

Great way to get to Manly and see Sydney harbour. We had a great ferry trip seeing the Sydney harbour's north and south heads. The waves were very large on the day we went which meant a wild boat ride. It was worth it seeing the waves crash on the rocks on the shore. You should go on the ferry as it is a bit of an icon for Sydney

Beautiful surprise. I'd just arrived at Sydney and I got this ferry to Manly... So beautiful! I could see the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge so near from me that I didn't want to sit down and relax, I just wanted to keep looking to every beautiful view of the city. I recommend!

a Sydney must do. nothing beats a Ferry ride from Sydney across our beautiful Harbour to Manly & back (or back by bus to see the suburbs & Spit Bridge). A walk up the Corso to the beautiful Manly Beach then around to Shelly Beach headland for a spot of whale watching. Or around the harbour edges to Fairlight Beach & beyond - even all the way to the Spit - 14 ks. Or just lie on the beach & chill out - Manly has it all.
Great Experiance. It was a great experience to travel from manly to Sydney City. You get a great view of all the sites and attractions Sydney has to offer.

Manly Ferry sightseeing. This is probably the most economical and relaxing trip you can do while visiting Sydney, it's a very pleasant ride on the harbour long enough to see the foreshore with it's multi million dollar homes and historical sites like Fort Dennison and Kirribilli House, but not too long that the kids will get bored. They run from Circular Quay to Manly wharf ever 5-10 minutes and it's a leisurely 30 minute ride that goes past the Opera House and offers great views of the city and the great Harbour Bridge. Lots of terrific photo ops, you see all the lovely hidden bays and beaches along the leafy north shore. At Manly you are able to wander the shops & cafés, walk to the world class beach. (Named by Captain Cook in the late 1700's after seeing the very masculine, manly indigenous people along the beach), or do the Manly to Spit Bridge Coastal Walk.

Relaxing yet enjoyable.. What a great way to see the beauty of Sydney Harbour.Catch the Manly Ferry at Sydney harbour . Try and get an seat outside. I find getting on the right hand side on the way to manly gives you a great view of the wealthy Eastern Suburbs and the heads . Then get on the right hand side again coming back to see middle head and the bushlands.Also at Manly pop up to the pub (The Ivanhoe) halfway down the corso on the left for lunch and go up to the 1 st floor and enjoy lunch on the balcony while watching thw world go by
Breathtaking!. The possible way ever to see Sydney Harbour for the first time, absolutely amazing!! Never cease to amaze me.

One of the best Ferry Trips in the world. Having travelled extensively, this ferry trip from Circular Quay to Manly is truly one of the most scenic trips you will ever experience. The ferry us slower than the Jetcat but that's the beauty of it that you can see Sydney's inner harbour residential living from Kirribilli House and the Opera House to Manly's hilly landscape. Not to be missed
Cheapest harbour cruise. Been on the Manly ferry a few times and I must say that it is the best and the cheapest way to see the harbour plus you get time to take in the sites of Manly.

Awesome. This is a great way to get our to Manly as well as have an awesome view of the harbour. Leaving Circular Key out past the Harbour Bridge and then past the Opera House before headed out to Manly is the way to do it. Was about $15 (I think, or thereabouts). If in Sydney definitely do this.

Fast and efficient. Great way to see the opera house, harbour, bridge and harbour islands. $15 for a return ticket and they run (like clockwork) every half an hour. Gets a bit choppy as you approach Manly but not too bad. Sit outside for best photo opportunities. Manly is well worth a visit- beautiful on a sunny day- we went in August and sat on the beach watching the whales- fantastic!

Great photo opportunities. The Manly ferry gives you another opportunity and different angles to get wonderful photos of the Sydney harbor and opera house. It is a wonderful, cheap way to get a boat side on the harbor. I highly recommend it. It was not choppy at all when we caught the ferry.

Bumpy ride...but great views!. The Manly Ferry is something you must do if you ever come to Sydney - dirt cheap and really family friendly...except for the bumpy ride on the second half of the journey, - my mother gets seasick, but we loved the motion of the waves crashing against the ferry, while watching beautiful Sydney harbour, and of course the opera house fade away, as we arrived in Manly.

Sydney skyline from Manly Ferry. The Manly Ferry is a great way to see Sydney from the water. The ferry leaves Circular Quay right in the city and passes between the Sydney Harbour Bridge on the left and the Sydney Opera House on the right. Both iconic views are so close up. The ferry heads out with good views of North Head one side and the Eastern Suburbs the other. Sailing past The Heads(where it can be a little choppy) and into Manly Wharf.The journey takes 30 minutes and the ferry always leaves dead on time. From Manly Wharf it is a short walk to Manly Corso and a lovely long sandy beach.The ferry has two decks,most of the seating being indoors, but there are outside areas too for people wanting to see the Sydney skyline as they come into Circular Quay and take photos.

Excellent!. Cheap as chips and a wonderful way to see the harbour in all its glory!! The views of the opera house and bridge together were breathtaking! We got off at Manly (such a pretty place) and spent a couple of hours around the beach area having lunch before heading back on the ferry for yet more of the wonderful views. I am so glad we did this!

The best way to see Sydney and a decent set of folks too!!. The Manly ferry is a must for any tourist to Sydney it is the best way to see the beautiful harbour sights, there really is no finer way that to take the 30 minute journey across the bay Day OR Night, also yesterday the Ferry team helped to restore my faith in good old fashioned values of decent people living in the UK if I had left my wallet on a train or a bus the likelihood of getting it back would have been pretty slim, and should I have got it back it probably would have been at least without the cash I had in it. Yesterday I found that here in Sydney that’s not the case, I left my wallet on the 7:40am Manly Ferry from Circular Quay, I didn't realise that I had done it and it was only at 1pm when I tried to buy lunch that I have the sinking feeling that it had gone. When I got to the Quayside not only was my wallet therewith cash, and cards and my driving licence but with a huge smile attached and lots of really kind people who re-assured me that Australia is a wonderful place for tourists.

A spectacular way to see some of Sydney's icons . The ferry trip across to Manly is a spectacular way to see some of Sydney's most iconic sights. You get to see the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House from an angle where you can really appreciate their setting. The view changes with time of day, so you can make the trip several times and always see something different. Highly recommended!

Excellent way to see Sydney at a fair price!. I took my partner who doesn't frequent Sydney on a ferry to Manly - she was blown away by the amazing views and the kindness of the staff operating the ferries and the ticket booths. We accidentally went to the wrong wharf when attempting to board our ferry to manly, but the ticket machine operators were very understanding and allowed us to get through to the correct wharf without a hassle. The ferry itself was very warm on the inside (perfect for our cold Friday night winter trip) and offered a wonderful view of the city from both inside and outside on the deck. I would really recommend taking a trip to Manly from Circular Quay using Manly Ferry if you're looking for that perfect photo of Sydney!

One of the best Ferry trips in the world. What better way to see the best part of spectacular Sydney Harbour then on the Manly Ferry. An inexpensive 30 minute ride between Circular Quay in Sydney and Manly Wharf the gateway to Sydney's northern beaches.

Great way to see Sydney Harbour. The Sydney ferries are iconic. If you want to see Sydney Harbour then this is the way to do it. Take the ferry to Manly beach which is one of Sydney's best, spend a few lazy hours swimming, walking or eating and then return. Other ferries such as the Mosman Wharf loop are also beautiful and it is a nice thing to do in the evening. Even when the swells are high it is a lot of fun.

The best of Sydney, to see the best of Sydney. Manly Ferries are historic but modern, cosy but fresh, exciting but conservative and very, very safe.The trip from Sydney's Circular Quay, or vice versa - Manly to Sydney, is one of the most beautiful, charming, and important items on your sight seeing agenda. Whether you're a local or a tourist, you MUST do the Manly Ferries.It's easy to buy a ticket - Opal cards are just coming in now, and various day cards, week cards etc are also available. The ticket operators are so easy to communicate with and very helpful if you explain what you might need, to get the best deal.Make sure you give youself time - ferries go every half hour in the mornings and evenings and also during the day (not sure the times.) It's easy to look these things up online.The trip is around 35 mins one way. From the Sydney end you can find the right pier by looking at the signs above the entrances. Find a great seat next to a window, near the front, or up the back. You can also go outside, but the view from inside is so spectacular, don't stress if you don't get one.If you're a tourist stay on the eastern side of the ferry - that is the one pointing towards the operahouse. If you're a local - go on the otherside, you'll be amazed at the gorgeous sandstone cliffs and bush.Before you take off look at North Sydney! it's almost as big as central Sydney for business, and contains the historic Luna Park on the foreshores. Notice also the gorgeous small ferries and other vessels in service, the little Alexander, Charlotte, and super Dawn Fraser...wonderful vessels travelling up Sydney's beautiful waterways, the Parramatta River etc.If you're taking pictures, take them out of an open window or from the deck around the sides. No good pictures can be taken through glass.On the way, note the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge, the beautiful historic rocks area to the western side of the quay. (convict built).ON your way out on the starboard side notice the elite Eastern Suburbs of Sydney with the beautiful mansions and lovely views. Note Fort Denison, and the lovely little bays and yachts.On the port side you can see Kirribilli House, and the lovely Northern Suburb bays of Mosman etc. You'll see beautiful, old gold, Sydney Sandstone - the rock which built Sydney! The golden colour of Sydney Sandstone and the pink of the Hawksbury sandstone is something you;ll see resounding in the buildings around the area.Look and relax while watching the yachts, other ferries, seagulls, and keep an eye out for whales!!! During the winter seasons you might see a spurt out to sea!Towards the heads you'll find the water gets a little rougher - rarely unbearable, sometimes a gentle rock, sometimes a fun roller coaster - these ferries are sturdy, safe and have Masters at the wheel who know these waters like their own front yard....you're safe. Whenever the swell is too dangerous the ferries stop. Simple as that.North Head is the large headland poking out from north to south. It contained the old Quarantine station - people travelling in ships had to stop there if there was anything nasty aboard.!The lookout from the National Park on North Head is one of the most astounding in the world. Take a taxi to the top, a bike (you can hire them in Manly if you've got the fortitude to ride) or walk. A walk up the hill should take about an hour. A car trip only 5-7 mins. It's astonishing, jawdroppingly beautiful, and a scene that famous painters like Arthur Streeton relished.As you head toward Manly you'll see the lovley bushland, gold sandstone cliffs, and seaside living that IS the Northern Beaches. Watercraft, restaurants, bungalows set in the bushland, high units with wonderful views...and beaches, some secluded, some frantic. Soak it all in, it doesn't matter which side of the ferry you're on. Manly is a treat for the senses.You can eat Manly, drink Manly, soak up Manly, feel Manly, walk Manly, even buy some of Manly...from the foreshores of Manly Harbour to the west and it's gorgeous still beach, bars and wharf life, to the incomparible Manly Beach to the east. You'll just love it. The Manly Corso joins the two areas like an artery of life - buzzing with people, souvenirs, business and restaurants. Too Touristy?? Get a life. THIS is the life. Manly Ferries is one of the BEST things you can do in Sydney. (oh...and to top it off, why don't you catch the little ferry around to Mosman, and go to the Taronga Park Zoo....WHAT a day!!!)

A 'must do' in Sydney. If you are not from Sydney, one of the loveliest things you can do is take the Ferry to Manly. We love to take the ferry and make a day trip and we live here. It is much quicker than driving and so peaceful and relaxing. You get to enjoy the harbour sights and sounds. Make a day trip and eat at one of the many fish restaurants in Manly - The Fish Cafe up the road is great. We also love Hugos on the wharf for the most spectacular pizza, salads and they are famous for cocktails- even non-alcoholic ones for us. We usually grab ice-cream at Movenpick, but there are about 5 great ice-cream shops that I can think of in a short walking distance of the Ferry. Hmm makes me want ice-cream now. There are many surf shops and cute little stores in the "village centre". Walking around Manly, eating ice-cream, lazing on the beach in the sea breeze (all year- but rugged up in winter) and then returning to the city on the Ferry is just a great day trip as a couple or for a family.

best (& cheapest) way to see the harbour. Takes about 20 mins. but for a few dollars you get to see all of the harbour from the bridge to both north and south heads! if you're lucky you may also get to see dolphins (and whales)!Also gives you a taste of what may be worth seeing more of, like the spit bridget to manly wharf; taronga zoo, watsons bay etc...

Day out at Manly. A few weeks ago we met at Circular Quay with friends from Newcastle and caught the ferry to Manly. We walked around the foreshores and had lunch in a Hotel overlooking the water.The meal was great and the view was very picturesque. We caught the bus & train from home into Sydney from the Western Suburbs, ferry to Manly and back, then back home again all for $ 2.50 (using our Senior Card). What a great day out and so cheap. I would highly recommend it.

Ticket to Ride. This is truly one of the best boat trips in the world. Takes you past plenty of Sydney's landmarks. Harbour bridge, Opera house and all the beaches. Half hour later arrive at Manly for a swim in the still harbour waters or the surf at world famous Manly beach. Have a drink, lunch or just take away fish and chips. Walk around to Shelly Beach. If you want to snorkel this is the spot. Fish everywhere only 50 metres off the beach and even small reef sharks too.All in all a great day out.

A glorious half hour ferry trip to Sydney's best surf beach. The Manly Ferry gives a stately ride from the city centre to Manly, arguably Sydney's finest surf beach. It travels past bays, inlets and headlands and even a stretch of open sea, affording glorious sights - all for minimal cost.

Great, cheap way to see the harbour. And if you are after a thrill ride, do it during a storm with big seas. Truly one of the best ways to see the harbour and Sydney. Head across to Manly for lunch and then make your way back to town as the sunsets and all the lights come on.
Bargain cruise. Just do it. Pick a sunny day. Sit back and relax. For a complete experience sit at the area on the bow. Cafe average but views spectacular.

Great weather a bonus. The old Sydney / Melbourne rivalry exists but as a visitor from the south I must admit Sydney and the harbour makes a visit a hit. Every visit I take my overseas visitors to Manly on the ferry. A great way to see another side of the city. Blue cloudless skies added to the experience. Ferries run regularly and recommend a day pass for public transport. Don't miss it!

Great way to see the Harbour. Fantastic and cheap way to fill in 3 hours with amazing views of Sydney Harbour and going to Manly which is also picturesque. Easy to purchase tickets and get on and off.

Visiting Manly is a must. Ferry is an easy way of getting to Manly. Ferries are regular and gives great views of Fort Canning, the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House and the North of Sydney. Not expensive either

A grand day out. If you travel in Sydney with children on a Sunday, be sure to get your funday ticket at an outlet or machine (not on the bus) - that way you'll get this amazing trip for a few bucks.The ferry to manly is big, has a cafe and is quite stable (until you pass the Heads). It takes you past some lovely spots that can be mapped for later trips by car.The ferry stop itself is quite fun with a good lolly shop and it is very well situated on the way to Manly beach.
on time with no fuss. it was my first experience on the manly ferry and it was a great first experience. no fuss, on time and the staff were nice and helpful.

Best way to see Sidney Harbour and some of its outlying coastal areas.. Recommended by Ausies and other nationalities whilst cruising from Auckland to Sidney.The best way to view Sidney Harbour and some of its outlying coastal areas. The ferry was clean, punctual and excellent value for a couple of retired Brits. Very surprised when I realised that we could both travel for five Aus dollars round trip. One point of interest, the beach is not adjacent to where you get off the ferry. Just walk for 5-10 minutes straight ahead through Manly town when you get off the ferry and you will come to the main beach.

Take a ride over to Manly. Great trip over on the ferry to Manly, the weather was not the best but it didn't matter the scenery was amazing with views to the Harbour, The Opera House, The Sydney Harbour Bridge and more. Went for a chilly walk down through the mall to Manly beach. Definitely recommend a inexpensive way to see the attractions from the water.

A very pleasant surprise. What a great surprise. Went to the ticket window to purchase 2 return tickets to manly on the ferry. The attendant asked if I had a seniors card (the grey hair gave me away). On producing the basic qld seniors card it cost me $5.00 for a return trip for two!! Couldn't believe it. Great ride and harbour views. Clean vessel and on time over and back. A must for any visitor to Sydney.

A must do for visitors and locals is the fabulous Circular Quay to Manly Ferry ride and back. This is a fantastic ferry ride and you have enjoy some time at Manly at the beach, having lunch and just enjoying the time by the water.

While in Sydney, find time to see Manly!. After getting off the cruise ship where we met several Australians, the popular recommendation was to take the Ferry ride to Manly. We did it & its totally worth it. Talk about a picture book, this area is beautiful. Both water & land areas were neat to see. Seeing both areas of Manly & Sydney by water gives you a bigger picture of this area.

A definite thing to include on your bucket list. Absolutely beautiful. This has got to be a must do when visiting sydney. We travelled over to visit the manly aquarium, which was good. The ferry trip was by far the best part. Gorgeous views of a beautiful city.

Best trip in town. Despite foul weather and heaving water we enjoyed two return trips on the Manly ferry in April. We have stayed in Manly itself in the past and getting off a plane from UK after 22 hours, taking the train to Circular Quay and then riding the ferry to Manly just takes away all the pain. The boats can get crowded at times but that is all part of the fun. The walk to the beach has been enhanced as there are more good food outlets and shops since we first visited several years ago. It is definitely a "must do" when in Sydney.

Take a slow ride on the Manly Ferry. Recommend take two trips to manly on the slow ferry1.on a sunny day with blue sky to see Sydney harbour and Manly at their best2.on a stormy day to see and experience the Sydney swell through the heads,more fun than a roller coaster.Warning if the fast ferry is not running then be prepared for a bumpy ride and to get wet if you are outside.Note may have to hang on outside.Take your camera and your cossie(Aussie for swimming costume)

This ferry is the best way to see the harbor!. This ferry is great to see the harbor! And when in Manly, go to see the surfer's beach, better then Bondi! There are two kinds of ferries, the fast one (15 minutes) and the regular one (30 mins). I suggest you take the fast one, there is a couple of dollars of difference per ride, so it's worth it. The ferry starts from circular quay.

A great way to se the habour. When in Sydney take the time to catch a ferry from Circular Quay to Manly. Buy a return ticket and enjoy the ride. It is the best way to see Sydney Harbour and it's many attractions without trying to find parking or getting that unobstructed view from land. Once you get to Manly take time to visit the Corso and shop in many of the souvenir and surf shops. There are also many cafes along the beach front promenade to take a break. Manly beach is also an iconic tourist attraction. If driving head up to North Head and the old Quarantine Station for breathtaking views of the heads and the city skyline from a different perspective. Well worth a look.

Worth doing. Yes, it's a touristy thing to do, yes it can sometimes be crowded, yes the cost of tickets can add up (for families), but this is seriously the best way to get to Manly.Mix with locals and visitors, as you serenely glide across Sydney Harbour. If you want to get the best shots of the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge when leaving Circular Quay, make sure you head to the outer deck at the end of the ferry. It's from this position, that you'll get the best photos when leaving the quay.

Manly Sydney Harbour Ferry. I've always thought using the good old Sydney to Manly ferry is a good way of looking at the harbor. You might not get a commentary, buts its a very good cheap harbour cruise. You go pastall the good stuff on your way to Manly. Lets face it, its always good to go Manly anyway, lots to do, see and eat while your in Manly.

The best way to Manly. The trip on the Manly Ferry was a great way to get to Manly Beach and also see the Sydney Harbour bridge and Opera House for unobstructed views. The ferries are frequent and relatively inexpensive especially if you buy a weekly pass for the ferries, trains, and buses.

Manly Ferry - a must. Very efficient and reasonable way to get from Sydney to Manly Beach. Lots of room inside if weather is poor, trip is only 30 minutes. You will see cruise ships, sail boats, and fisherman as you travel. Catch the evening one and watch the sunset.

A great way to view Sydney Harbour. Taking a trip on the Manly Ferry is a great way to view Sydney Harbour with its iconic bridge and Opera House views and as well as this you get to enjoy Manly with its beach and many walks. The ferries are frequent and relatively inexpensive and a Sydney experience that mustn't be missed.

Third class ride, but first class scenery, destination, fun day. Water, people watch, opera house, Sydney Harbour bridge, , the entrance to the Harbour, sweet Old Fashioned Manly as a destination. A "must do" preferably not at rush hours, ENJOY.WALK THE Corso and walk to Shelley Beach or turn left as your exit the ferry, and walked forever (ten miles) on theTRULY Scenic Walkway, stopping to swim in Fairlight Tidal pool. A priceless day!! An essential component to doing Sydney!!

Why drive when there is a ferry. We thoroughly enjoyed our 30 minute trip from Circular Quay to Manly. We have done this several times but you never get sick of the fabulous Sydney Harbour. On board our ferry we were lucky enough to be entertained by a guitarist vocalist. Very soft and soothing as our crossing. Met up with family, strolled around the promenade and had a lovely luncheon on the balacony of the old Ivanhoe Hotel watching the world walk pass. The ferry staff were very quick boarding everyone. Plenty of seating to choose from. Definitely take a jacket on the cooler days to sit outside.

A great Harbour cruise. Every time we visit Sydney we head for the Manly ferry. What a wonderful way to take in the beautiful views of the harbour, there is a charge of course but very reasonable considering the distance travelled.Manly is a great place to visit, the beach area is a very relaxing place to sit & watch the world go by, great eating places and interesting activities in the concourse. A wonderful way to spend a lazy day in the harbour environment.

Water Transport. Very easy to use. If you suffer from claustrophobia then this is not the right form of transport for you. Waiting for the ferry is like a cattle yard, everyone is pushing to get to the front.Great way to travel across the harbour if you don't mind crowds.

Pleasant ride with Manly ferry.. We took the ferry in the afternoon and it was nice experience. The ferry is well maintained and seats were plenty. Ample wide spaces and nice viewing deck. While returning we were able to secure a nice place to click pictures of the harbor. Overall nice and safe journey with Manly ferry.

Manly Ferry, a MUST do. Anyone visiting Sydney should put the Manly ferry trip on their must do list. The journey takes about 30 minutes, the harbour views are fantastic. If the weather is good try to get a seat upstairs at the front for the best view.Once at Manly its a short walk down The Corso to Manly beach. Their are plenty of dining options, from fancy restaurants to take away to a good pub meal.
Must do. Loved the ferry !great views one to op sightseeing everything about Sydney you pass by great and inexpensive Jump on a ferry for everything that's Sydney

Manly Ferry Review. Get the ferry from circular quay to Manly, and on the way pass the Opera House and Harbour Bridge (do not forget the camera) sit back and enjoy the ferry ride to Manly, great views from the ferry, trip on ferry about 25 mins, when in Manly stroll thru the shops, cafes and bars to the beach, take your footwear off and walk along the excellant sandy beach, also afew cafes on the watrrfront if you get hungry great place to be afew hours to enjoy.

A great way to see Sydney Harbour on the way to Manly. A great way to see Sydney Harbour on the way to Manly.A cheap, clean, safe and fun way to visit Manly while seeing the beautiful Sydney Harbour and "The Heads".You can appreciate how clean the harbour is and also the City of Sydney.As you approach Manly Wharf you'll be impressed by the convenience of this convenient mode of transport. Enjoy!

Great asking Tracks. Travelled to Manly by ferry which was a good way to see some of the waterways of Sydney. Once at Manly we walked up and over the hill, a little hard in some areas but truly a nice walk. Wish I had more time there.
Lunch for 2. Caught the fast ferry from circular Quay to manly - done lots of walking and some shopping and coffee & cake and lunch - great weather & great walk on manly beach

Great way to see the Harbour. Catching the Circular quay to Manly Ferry is the best way to see Sydney Harbour. The return trip is reasonable priced, less than AU$ 20. You get to see the million dollar views for a fraction of the price. Great photo opportunities of the Harbour bridge and the Opera house. If the weather is good you can sit on the open decks of the ferry or if it is a bit windy you can still see everything from inside the ferry. All in all a very worth while trip and don't forget to walk down to manly beach when you get there, great food places over there to help make an easy trip for the day.

Short Boat Ride to a Whole New World. The Manly Ferries not only give you great views to the Opera House, Sydney Harbor and the Harbour Bridege, but the short scenic ride gives you an entirely different view of the slower side of Sydney. Manly is a hip, but island-style oasis, a breath-taking change from the hubbub of downtown. Manly is a delight to both surfers and day-trippers. The waves are consistent, with a selection of onshore and outside breaks. Bars and casual restaurants abound. If you are a tourist, this is a half-day well spent!

Great views of the Harbour!. This ferry is an awesome way to experience the Harbour. You pass right by the opera house and the harbour bridge. It also has a wifi hotspot upstairs of the ferry which is really nice. The ride is smooth and it's nice to sit back, relax and enjoy the gorgeous views.

360 degree view of Sydney Harbour. The Manly ferries are the best way of viewing and taking in the Sydney Harbour and its iconic attractions - Opera House & the Harbour Bridge. Plus the Manly Beach which is a nice enjoying walk, nice beach and some good fish & chips.Ideally go for the Sunday Funday and get tickets for AUD 2.50 for whole day on all rides - train, ferries. Come to Central, take any train to Circular Quay and get in to the ferry waiting. Preferably go onto the upper deck and come on to the porch. Enjoy with family, kids.
great way to experience the harbour. sydney harbour is often rated as the best harbour in the world after a trip on the manly ferrys it's hard to disagree ! summer is the best time !

Manyly Ferry. Great views from the ferry accross Sydney Harbour and past the Heads. Inside and outsiade setting available Outside for the best views on a nice day. Arrive at manly walk up to the beach front, enjoy Fiosh & Chips on the beach reserve and return to Sydney on the Ferry A great time out at moderate cost.

THE best way to see the best harbour in the world for the cheapest price!. As we all know, the trip to Manly Beach crosses one of the most beautiful harbours in the world, Sydney Harbour.For years I have traveled this waterway by public transoprt, or to use it's better known name the Manly Ferry.Multi milliojn dollar views for only a few dollars. Mostly the trip is fairly calm and sedate, but on some occasions the Manly Ferry makes some of the scenes in Noah look like a walk in the park. It can get extremely rough.Some people like this, and only travel to Manly during the worst weather conditions.The boarding process is easy and quick, and as the larger ferries do not turn around, head straight for the pointy end furthest from the dock for a great view during the trip.You can buy multi trip tickets, Zoo tickets, all day tickets, and go on as many ferry trips as possible. I also highly recoment the ferry trip to darling harbour & Balmain.The larger ferries have food and drink available at reasonable prices.A great trip for the day is:Take River Cat from the wharf at Parramatta to Circular Quay, then jump on the Manly ferry, have lunch at one of the MANY eateries in Manly, then reverse the process. Just be mindful of the final ferry times for the Parramatta River Cat. The Manly ferry works till late, so even a nice romantic monnlight cruise is available.

Great trip , well worth away trip. Lovely day trip from Sydney to Manly, excellent views of the harbour and the opera house from the boat. Great way to spend a day, Manly is such a nice , bustling town, plenty shops, cafes, bars and restaurants along with a very nice beach. Great way to spend a day
Manly Ferry. A leisurely way to see our magnificent harbour. Lots of points of interest to keep little ones busy.

Best way to commute to/from work!. The very best way to commute to/from work! I catch the ferry pretty much every day from Monday to Friday and only gets better when there are whales and dolphins around! The view is breathtaking - def a must do in Sydney for anyone on holidays too!

Great way to see the harbour. Thee are several ways to get from Sydney's CBD to Manly. My favourite is the Manly ferry. It's a relatively quick way of seeing (and photographing) some of Sydney harbour's famous landmarks. From the skyscrapers beyond Circular Quay, the harbour bridge, Opera House, Botanical Gardens, the exclusive waterfront residences on the foreshores of Double bay, Rose Bay and Watsons Bay. Before long you're passing the mouth of the harbour, South Head and North Head. This is my favourite part of the journey, especially during stormy conditions - it can be a bit of a 'roller coaster' ride, something i have always enjoyed - but it may not be for the faint hearted. It only lasts a few minutes. Not long after you arrive at Manly - some 35 minutes later. The return trip is just as interesting, as you pass the mouth to Middle Harbour, with Balmoral Beach in the distance. At Middle Head we see the start of Sydney Harbour National Park, then we round Bradley's Head, most noticeable item of interest is The foremast of the cruiser HMAS Sydney, Australian vessel from WW1. The harbour side entrance to Taronga Park Zoo is then visible through the bushes on the right. Another quick view of Harbourside real estate, Fort Denison on the left and finally returning to Circular Quay. Summer months are the high season for cruise ships which dock on the western side of the Quay at the Internation Overseas Terminal. So ends a round trip with the Manly ferry. Please note: there are many attractions at Manly as well, no need to stay on the ferry. Ideal in summer, and Sydney's balmy winters.

A very beautiful part of Sydney. Manly is a must see in Sydney, make sure u catch a ferry there as it is part of the must see :)if you like Jazz, the long weekend in Oct, is the Manly Jazz Festival. Three days of non stop outdoor jazz , free..

Cheapest way to get out on our beautiful harbour. This is a beautiful trip. We've done it a few times as a family day out - the kids loved it and were particularly impressed with the pod of dolphins that followed us one day! We've recommended it to a number of interstate and overseas visitors recently and they've raved about it. The beautiful Manly Beach at one end and our amazing city at the other - what's not to like. If you're visiting Sydney and looking for a great day out, take the ferry to Manly, enjoy a relaxed lunch at one of the many fabulous restaurants (or just get some fish & chips and head down to the beach) and go for a stroll to Shelly Beach. If it's warm enough you can take a dip in the Fairy Bower rock pool on your way past.

A great and cheap way to see Sydney Harbour. When you come to Sydney you will have available to you quite a number of ways to see our beautiful harbour. Some are very expensive and some include meals, coffee etc. So what you want to do if up to you. However, if you just want to see a good view for really very little money, then get a return ferry ticket from Circular Quay to Manly. The trip takes less than an hour and the views on all sides and worth a million dollars. The ferries also come from another earlier age and have a history of their own. Some even made the trip from the UK to Sydney. This is one of the most relaxing ways to spend an hour in our city and is something that is easy to do and should suit all travellers. I'm a Sydney sider and I have done the trip a number of times.Why not get off at Manly, have a meal or a beer at the nearby pub and just get the next available ferry back to the Quay. Just do it.

Graceful old ladies. The trip on a Manly Ferry is well worth the effort. What a fantastic way to see the amazing Sydney Harbour. Everywhere you look there is a feast for your eyes. The ferries are a part of our heritage here in Sydney. There are faster ways to make the trip to Manly but none as pleasant. Sit outside and feel the breeze and maybe the salt in your face. And of course Manly is your destination. A great day out! Walk along The Corso and the Ocean Beach then stop and have some fish and chips or some icecream. In summer that beach and the water calls. Highly recommend to anyone.

Circular Quay to Manly. 7 miles from Sydney and 1000 miles from care. That's the famous Manly Ferry motto.A superb way to see the City of Sydney on the best harbour in Australia.25 minutes of happiness for the whole family. Even for the locals - leave the car at home and catch a bus or train to Circular Quay and board the Manly Ferry - you wont regret it.Fish & chips on the beach along with the seagulls or visit one of the many cafes and restaurant, it's your choice.Bill M

Manly Ferry. We live in Manly and catch the ferry many times a month.Always clean and very rarely not on schedule.For tourists leaving the Quay always sit out the back for best pictures of Opera House and framed city skyline with the bridge. If not out the back then travel the opposite side of the ferry for your return trip.Sit up stairs as in big seas outside downstairs may be damp.Avoid the 10.30 and 11.00 weekday ferries as there is usually a much smaller craft used on those runs.Don't forget they have Wi Fi.If using ferries on the weekends be aware they are usually very crowded so get to the queue at least 15 minutes before departure time and get a good coffee to while away the start of the trip. All rubbish to be dropped in containers on board.Enjoy

A great day out for visitors and locals alike... The Circular Quay area where you get on the ferry is a bustling, crazy focal point for many Sydney sights such as The Opera House and Harbour Bridge and also the historic Rocks area.Once you get on the ferry, its like a harbour cruise and journey all-in-one. The ferry goes past a lot of the eastern suburbs and you can see the harbourside mansions of Darling Point, Point Piper and more besides. Once in Manly, you have another hive of activity with the Manly Wharf area with bars and restaurants where the ferry terminal is, right through The Corso to the ocean beach. Have some fish and chips on the sand!

Best view of Sydney Harbour. No matter what time of day you get on the ferry its an amazing view. The trip from Manly to Circular quay takes about 30 -40 minutes about 20 minutes slower than the fast ferry. If you're in a rush probably not the right mode of transport for you. Its a beautiful relaxing journey. Highly recommend for anyone and everyone.

Always a winner. We regularly travel to and from Manly via the ferry,with a disabled passenger. To us it's always a winner--stunning views, economical fares, helpful staff, and plenty of fresh air! Then there is the wide range of choice for coffee and food from many cafes on and around the Corso area in Manly, and many easy walks to along the waterfront.

Manly ferry Sydney harbour. Living in Sydney I do a regular trip across the harbour on the Manly Ferry.It is a 30 minute leisurely trip from Manly to Circular Quay taking in all the sights of beautiful Sydney Harbour on the way. Spectacular. If you are not in a rush this is the only way to go, don't get the fast ferries. They run about every half hour and on the ferry is a cafe, toilets and wifi - you can only but Enjoy. Cost - not a lot around $6.00

Cheap way to see the harbour. Hop on the Manly ferry at Circular Quay and you cruise past the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House, Fort Denison and the expanse of the harbour. At Manly you can swim at a harbour beach or a surf beach, relax in a park or cafe and stroll along the coast.

Beautiful Harbour Trip. If you are ever visiting Sydney make sure you take the ferry from either Circular Quay to Manly or the other way round. Sydney Harbour is a beautiful harbour. On a sunning day sit outside and enjoy the scenery and when you get to Manly there are many lovely restaurants along Manly Beach front that are well worth the visit. Same goes as there are lots of restaurants around Circular Quay or the Rocks. A day well spent. There is always something to see on the harbour whether it is one the tall ships sailing around or yacht races. A must do for any visitor.

Circular Quay to Manly by Ferry & Return. What a great day out. I hadn't used this service for about 20 years. Myself and 3 friends boarded the ferry at approximately 10am to visit 2 other friends in Manly. I had forgotten how beautiful our harbour was. Plenty of seating and we were able to get up the front and spent time during the trip chatting to visitors from Canada about our beautiful country. Once we arrived at Manly we visited the Yacht Club and had a swim on Manly Beach. To finish the day we enjoyed a coffe on the Corso. We arrived back at Circular Quay at about 8pm. A great way to spend a spare day in Sydney

A great, inexpensive way to see the harbour.. A trip to Manly on the ferry is a great, economical way to see some of the harbour & gives a great vantage point from which to view both the Opera House & Harbour Bridge. There are plenty of places to grab lunch & take it to the beach, or dine in & enjoy the atmosphere.
Manly Ferry. If you only have a day in Sydney this is the must do attraction. Cath the ferry, walk down the Esplanade and dip your toes in Manly beach!

Circular quay to Manly. I walk for ten kilometres with sports and recreation group and travel by train, ferries and buses. Last week our group took ferry to Manly and we walked to Shelly Beach. Absolutely beautiful walk. Manly has many coffee houses along the way from ferries to the waft. We walked along Manly trails which range from short, scenic strolls suitable for all, including those in wheelchairs or with prams, to lengthy and challenging treks for more avid walkers.

Inexpensive Harbor Cruise. When I have visitors from overseas who have limited time and budgets I find the Manly Ferry a simple way to provide a Harbor Cruise alternative. What better way to end the trip with a walking through Manly and a picnic lunch.

perfect scenery around Sydney Harbour. It takes 30 mins to get to Manly from Circular Quey. Unforgettable experience you will have. The scenery around Sydney Harbour will makes you busy to take photos. It is a great day trip to Manly.

The $2.50 explore Sydney. This is for the over 60's and is a great day out. Purchase the $2.50 pension excursion ticket, hope a bus or train to circular quay,then the Manly ferry over to Manly, a short stroll through the mall to the beach, then back again, take your pick of any other ferries, always doing the round trip, make the last one of the day, the fast cat to Watsons Bay, if you get there before 4pm you are still in time for lunch at Doyles. Bus to Bondi Junction, via Bondi Beach. Bus or train back to where you are staying. This is a truly fantastic day on the harbour and all for $2.50

Not to be missed. We live in Sydney and always enjoy this trip whether just the two of us or with overseas visitors. Just catch the ferry from Circular Quay. Our magic harbour, the historic ferries and iconic Manly beach are a perfect mix. Time it right and you can return to see the sun setting over the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The ferries are large and you can sit inside or enjoy the views from the deck. It can be a very inexpensive day out for the whole family or a lovely day out for couples. Highly recommended.

Manley ferry. A must do thing when in Sydney, a ferry trip to Manley. Choose acalm day, becauseit can get very rough. Ittakes about half an hour, and the views and experienceis worth every penny. Manley is a pleasant resort with a very goog beach and good promenade for walking. Nice pubs and eateries, lots of shops to explore.a few hours in Manley will fly by. The return journey will offer good photo oportunities of the bridge and opera house , perhaps the most iconic aussie picture you are likely to take, and i can see why Australians are stating they have the most picturesque harbour in the world, but personally I think the picure of the Hudson bridge with Manhattan as the backdrop is just as iconic and far more dramatic.

Manly Ferry. Forget the harbour cruises, the Manly Ferry is the best value way way to see the iconic sights of Sydney. A 30 minute trip from Circular Quay, spectacular views, large comfortable ferry, indoor and outdoor seating, coffee and soft drinks available, a return ticket is 15 dollars. Step off the ferry at Manly and it is a short walk to the surf beach. A ten minute walk from the surf beach will bring you to the smaller, sheltered Shelley Beach. Highly recommended.

Love this Ferry. This is such a cheap easy and refreshing way to see the harbour, head over to Manly and soak up some beach, great cafes and styley shops (like the Shop Next Door cafe and surf shop). This is a must do in Sydney!

Beautiful view, economical & fun. A great way to see the rainbow bridge, opera house, and the cliff coastlines around Sydney. One way trip costs 7.20 AUD as of May 2014. Access to Manly Beach is an extra perk.

Great way to see Sydney Harbour. The 30 minute ferry trip from Circular Quay in the CBD to Manly is just beautiful. The ferry is large and comfortable with coffee, drinks and snacks sold on board. There is both indoor and outdoor seating and the views are spectacular. A walk around the surf beach area of Manly and around the walkway to Shelley Beach and then trying one of the many quality restaurants or coffee shops makes it a lovely place to visit. The return ferry journey is equally as beautiful. It makes for a great, restful day seeing one of the best harbours in the world.

One of the best things to do in Sydney. Unlike most people, we went from Manly to Sydney City not the other way around so the ferry was quiet, we got to walk around (push the stroller) without any hassle and take a million photos of the Opera House and the Bridge. We took the ferry on quiet a cold day and it was still an incredible experience. I am really glad that we did this.

Enjoy the Breeze & the Views. *) The best way to see Sydney from the water is from the back of the Manly ferry as it pulls away from Circular Quay. To the left is the Opera House and to the right is the Harbour Bridge. 30 minutes later the ferry arrives at the beautiful, laid back seaside village of Manly.*) Try to sit outside and enjoy the sunshine and the view.*) Cheap tickets, you can buy these in Circular Quay right near the train station. Short walk from the wharf in Manly to the beach, go through the Corso.*) Excellent Views of Opera House from ferry.*) Carry a jacket, if you are sitting out, you will need it, especially in the evenings.*) Free wifi available on ferry.*) There is Max Brenner and Nandos at Manly Wharf. Hot Chocolates and Suckao at Max Brenner are very popular. White Suckao costs AUD 6.50.*) Take the Ferry back from Manly Wharf to Circular Quay. Walk around the area for sometime.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://sydneygoldcoastbrisbaneviasingapore.blogspot.com/

A nice way to spend an afternoon. We enjoyed a lovely afternoon in Manly and it all starts with the Manly ferry. A 30minute ride each way between Circular Quay and Manly with geat veiws around the harbour as you travel. We were lucky to see the harbour at sunset as we came back into Sydney and I highly recommend you time your trip as its spectacular.

Sydney Harbour at Sunset. We were lucky enough to be on the ferry coming back from Manly as the sun was setting on the city. It made for some amazing views. I would recommend to try to time it if you are able to.Queues can be big on holidays. We waited for an hour each way on Easter Sunday.

A Relaxing 30 minutes. What a great way to take a short break from the hustle and bustle of Sydney,as a senior $2-50 gets you an all day ticket on the ferries so why not take a ride to Manly.The weather has a lot to do with how enjoyable your trip will be,either sitting in the sun with a coffee you have purchased on board or hanging on if the weather is a bit rough and the swell through the heads makes your trip a thrill.When you get to Manly,. a coffee at one of the coffee shops or fish and chips,take away,and sit by the water makes your day complete.So whether you are a local or a visitor,go for a Manly ferry ride and have great day.

Best way to see the area. Best value buy a 7 day ticket covers all the ferries and buses. Stopped in manly for 7 days used ferry at least twice a day be careful when its a bit rough as waves can break over the front outdoor seating area.

Beautiful Way To See All Of Sydney Harbor. This is an inexpensive way to go from Circular Quay to Manly and see all of the amazing harbor along the way. You get perfect, unobstructed view of the Opera House and so many other beautiful things along the way. It's only like $15 pp round trip and you can ride inside the cabin or outside.

Cheap and beautiful way to see Sydney. Getting on a ferry to manly is a really cheap day out in Sydney. Seeing the city from the water is really something and Manly is laid back and beachy and much nicer than Bondi.
Easiest way to see the harbour!. no planning needed as the ferries are frequent, affordable - it's a no-brainer.The destination is also one of Sydney's best spots

Is there a better way to see Sydney?. What's not to like?! Value for money; spectacular views in all directions; Manly and its great beach, pubs, restaurants and generally funky vibe; a chance to put your feet up for half an hour each way while enjoying the trip. Even the chance, as we had, to see whales leaping clear of the water down by the North Head.Some random do's and don'ts: If you want an outdoor seat, you need to be pretty single-minded to beat the hordes of Japanese tourists who also have no compunction in standing in front of your seat to block the view while taking their own pix. There really should be an insistence on all passengers staying seated. You might want to have a fleece/cardie handy. The further you sail down the harbour towards the Heads, the cooler and breezier it gets. You have been warned!Definitely worth half a day for the ferry and the chance to stroll round Manly.

A must do! See the harbor and northern beaches. Great way to see Sydney harbor and experience what the northern beaches have to offer....beautiful beaches, hip restaurants and shops on the corso, excellent surf watching. Much cooler than Bondi and the ferry makes it much easier to get to.

A "must do" for Sydney visitors. This is one of the most convenient and cheapest tours in Sydney. The Many ferry provides the best views of Sydney Harbour during its 30 minute trip. Alight at Manly and a 10 minute stroll along the Corso brings you to the blue Pacific surf spilling onto the golden sands of Manly Beach. The beachfront is dotted with pubs, cafes and restaurants. The more active can take the walkway South around the rocky foreshore to Fairy Bower beach. The ferries depart every half hour until late and one of the better sights is to return to Circular Quay to watch the sunset over the harbour or later to see the Opera House and lights of Sydney by night.

Best way to see Sydney is from the water!. The ferry is relatively cheap and you can get a good idea of the harbour layout, see where the rich live and check out the zoo. Manly is a spectacular beach, note the colour of the sand and take a walk to the surf side. Then on your way home you come around a headland and get a fabulous view of the bridge, city and Opera House. Try this at sunset as a Sydney resident I'm still overcome by this.

Cheaper than a harbour cruise, and more fun. Cheaper than a harbour cruise, and more fun - you can get off at Manly, walk to the surfing beach and around the headland to Shelly Beach, go snorkelling, climb to the top of the cliff and see the ocean, rent a kayak, have an icecream, eat fish and chips on the beach, watch the sunset... "seven miles from Sydney and a hundred miles from care" used to be on a sign on the ferry when I was a kid!

A must for tourists!. A short ride across the heads on the Manly Ferry while capturing the beautiful vista of Sydney Harbour, this is a must for the discerning traveller. A cheap mode of transport that takes in all the harbour and the many sites that surround the foreshore. For a slightly more expensive journey, you can take the hydrofoil (a little more luxurious) where you will arrive at this well known beachside spot where there are many restaurants/cafes to delight the tastebuds. For anyone travelling on a cruise, the Manly Ferry/hydrofoil is only steps away at Circular Quay that will whisk you away for a day of fun and frivolity with light-hearted entertainment, wonderful food amid the ambience of this gorgeous seaside town. A fabulous way to experience Sydney Harbour.

an essential activity for all ages, tourists and locals. As an older life-time Sydney resident, I've used the Manly ferry 'for pleasure' once or twice a year for more than 60 years, and never tire of it. Now, I usually take grandchildren, and share their discovery of the harbour. Ferries leave Circular Quay every half an hour and take almost half an hour to reach Manly. Every part of Sydney Harbour and its water traffic is interesting.I'd suggest tourists walk around Manly for an hour or more, and in summer you can swim either at the surf beach or a quieter harbour beach adjacent to the ferry wharf. There is a very pleasant walk on a good path starting at the Southern end of the beach, to another sheltered small beach - 'Fairy Bower', less than an hour for the return journey. There are plenty of places to eat. The best 'takeaway' fish and chip shops are close to the beach. There is a good fish restaurant, 'Garfish', close to the ferry wharf. Sydney Ferries was government-owned and operated until a few years ago. Now privately owned, there are signs of cost-cutting e.g. on my recent use of the ferry, there were long queues for tickets, so that arriving 10 minutes before departure wasn't enough time to get that ferry. Most of my previous experiences, though, would rate '5 out of 5'.
Unforgettable trip across & back the harbour is very picturesque. Lovely trip across the harbor & the walk up to manly beach is short & then if you can walk around to shelly beach. A nice day out

Manly Ferrys. What a great way to see one of the best harbors in the world by ferry if first time or not it's a great way to get around weather you go to manly or taronga zoo darling harbour it's a great day out or do what I have done go explore just jump on a ferry kid friendly and there is a lot Moore to see around the waterways and no traffic enjoy your travels Targee

The BEST way to enjoy Sydney Harbour!!!!. A ride on the Manly Ferry (especially on a sparkling sunny day) has got to be the best way to experience Sydney and the Harbour, as well as beautiful Manly Beach, a short walk along The Corso (the pedestrian shopping stretch between the Habour wharf and the ocean beach)

A Limited Time in Sydney. We recently hosted some American visitors who only had 5 hours free time when passing through town and had to think how to convey the essence of Sydney in the short time available. We decided on a ferry ride to Manly. The ferry had seating that allowed six of us to sit facing each other so we could talk easily while viewing the lovely harbour vistas. A short walk along the beach at Manly showed off the seaside lifestyle and then coffee at one of the many pavement cafes before the trip back dropped our visitors off at Circular Quay with plenty of time to catch their plane. Also a possibility for people on a cruise who have had their fill of shopping?

Spectacular Cruise on Sydney Harbour. Th easiest and certainly the cheapest way of seeing Sydney harbour is a trip on the iconic Manly Ferry. This is the scheduled method of public transport between Manly & Circular Quay (downtown Sydney) and is used by many commuters during peak hour. It takes you right up the Harbour and across the Heads (the opening to the Ocean) and the ride here can be slightly less smooth depending on the size of the swell. Don't worry it only takes about five mins to cross & you won't get sick. No commentary, but you see absolutely every thing and locals are only too happy to answer your questions you may have. Wander around Manly & take the return journey or if pressed for time there is a slightly more expensive "fast ferry"

tony wollongong unreal. great harbour views for a pretty good price. if you get the right weather it is on par with anyboat ride in the world.plus at each end of the trip you have either a world class beach or the the great city of sydney. plenty of choices for food and drink.most weekends their is some form of entertainment at manly that will please just about all tastes.

Best way to see the harbour. A trip to Manly by ferry is one of the best ways to see the harbour as opposed to the expensive cruises on offer. You can sit outside if not too hot or rainy and for those who need an Internet hit there is a wifi section on top level. Once in Manly walk down the Corso to main beach and if especially keen walk around to Shelley Beach via one of the nicest walks in Sydney.

Manly - A Thousand Miles from Care!. As a regular Manly Ferry traveller I am a big fan. A day trip to Manly is a highlight for all my overseas visitors. The trip is leisurely but can be exciting when there is a big swell and the ferry crosses the open water between the heads. On the trip over there are photo opportunities all around and a picture of the Opera House from the ferry is a must. Once in Manly - a seaside village- its a tradition to have fish and chips and/or take a scenic 500m walk around to the sheltered Shelly Beach. This beach is the only west-facing beach on Australia's East coast and for snorkelers and divers the protected Cabbage Tree Bay is filled with unique marine life such as the Eastern Blue Groper, the Weedy Sea dragon, Gloomy Octopus, and Little Penguin. For the more energetic a walk up hill to North Head - via North Fort - provides fantastic cliff top views back to the city. A ferry trip back at dusk or at night shows a side of Sydney not seen by everyone. At dusk there is a chance to get a great sunset picture with the sun setting in the west behind the bridge.

Always love a trip on the Manly ferry. Always the nicest way to get into Sydney from Manly. It always reminds me of my childhood. I also have fond memories of taking my own children on the Manly ferry. Beats driving and sitting in traffic and the views are spectacular of the Bridge and Opera house.

Great on a sunday. A wonderful way to spend a day while in sydney.Especially if you are travelling with children under 16 as on sundays you're entitled to purchase the family funday ticket @ $2.50 each which entitles you to unlimited travel on sydney's public transport all day which includes the manly ferry.

Great way to see the Harbour. As a local I always take visitors on the Manly Ferry, its cheaper than doing a tour on one of the companies and you can see everything, Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Pinchgut Island, Luna Park.

Best way to see the harbour and beaches. This is a definite Sydney must do. You could take an expensive harbour cruise, but this is better on the budget and you can grab a great meal on the esplanade in Manly.Starting at Circular Quay, which is in between the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House, the journey takes 30 minutes - offering lots of photos opportunities of both structures - and travels through the harbour staying inside the heads (the sea entrance to Sydney Harbour) to port of Manly.Manly is a surf beach with miles of golden sand, a good variety of restaurants and take-aways, pubs and stores.It's a great way to experience both the city and coast of Sydney.

Cheaper than a harbour cruise & more relaxing. I have to confess that I'm biased as I live in Manly and the ferry is my daily commute into work in the city - it doesn't get much better than that!! Admittedly there is no commentary or meal service that you may get on a harbour cruise, but being able to sit and relax, watch the other voyagers, smell the sea air (and maybe a few diesel fumes) or read a book, beats having to listen to a constant flow of information coming through a crackly speaker. There's plenty of information available on line if you're wanting to know anything about what's around you. And if you're feeling peckish, the little café on board will suffice.

Get out there and enjoy bushland and the sea!. A trip by ferry to Manly allows a visitor to Sydney to appreciate the extraordinary connection between one of the world's great cities and the immediacy of the sea, surf, beach, towering cliffs and unspoiled bushland. The ferry rides enables a visitor to capture what it must have been like for the unwilling migrants who were first brought to these shores. Manly itself is a seaside town. Access to the corner named Fairy Bower along the walkway with its cafes makes a lunchtime visit great fun. This is an excursion visitors and residents of Sydney alike enjoy taking in all seasons and especially in the Summer and Spring. We take our Canadian friends there each time they visit us. It has become something of a ritual for Bob to take a dip in the Pacific Ocean on this side of the world.

Great way to see the city and a good day out.
